docs.lead_paragraph: New York's largest janitors' union signed a tentative three-year agreement with the real estate industry yesterday, seven weeks before the contract deadline. Both sides said the surprise move was intended to minimize uncertainty during an anxious time for the city's businesses. The development is a far cry from the usual practice, when every third Thanksgiving the managers of Manhattan's office towers warn thousands of tenants of a possible janitors' strike that could force them to clean their own offices and haul their garbage out themselves.

headline.main: Citing Sept. 11, 2 Sides Avert Janitors' Strike

docs.abstract: New York's largest janitors' union signs tentative three-year agreement with real estate industry, seven weeks before contract deadline; both sides say surprise move was intended to minimize uncertainty during anxious time for city; terms of tentative pact outlined; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate leaders and the Bush administration agreed today to bipartisan high-level negotiations by Congress and the White House on an economic stimulus package, but House Republicans blocked any talks, at least for the moment. ''I don't understand the need for this summit,'' said Representative Bill Thomas of California, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. And John Feehery, spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, said: ''Our leadership is pretty leery of some kind of a budget summit. The Senate needs to get a bill passed.''

headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMIC LEGISLATION

docs.abstract: Senate leaders and Bush administration agree to bipartisan high-level negotiations by Congress and White House on an economic stimulus package, but House Republicans block any talks, at least for moment; Senate begins debating Democratic bill which, unlike recently passed House version, lacks votes for passage; Democrats want stimulus package to have heavy emphasis on help for unemployed; Republicans of both houses are emphasizing tax cuts; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a patch of land that once held pine, spruce and oak trees, an auto-parts maker opened a modern-looking manufacturing plant here five years ago. Over on the east side of town, another company makes computer circuit boards on a former military base. And an hour and a half to the northwest, a telecommunications equipment factory sits in a field that produced cotton a decade ago. With great fanfare, much of the Southeastern United States diversified its economic base over the last two decades, luring giant auto companies, sprouting new technology centers and raising hopes that the region would not just enjoy greater prosperity but also weather hard times better in the future than it had in the past.

headline.main: The Rust Belt With a Drawl; States of the Interior South Mired in Worst Downturn In Nearly Two Decades

docs.abstract: Interior Southern states--Alabama, Arkansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi and Tennessee--suffers more economic problems than other regions as its manufacturing decline accelerates; partly because of region's efforts to diversify, and partly in spite of them, old Bible Belt has become nation's new Rust Belt, suffering first and worst from nation's economic distress; scene in Gadsden, Ala, detailed; chart; graph; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Deal Near on Cheap Drugs For Poor Countries Negotiators at the World Trade Organization meeting in Qatar all but clinched a deal that would give developing countries greater access to cheap generic drugs to fight epidemics like AIDS and malaria. The American-brokered compromise defused a dispute between rich and poor nations that had threatened to scuttle the trade talks. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The World Trade Center tragedy ushered in understanding for the crippling symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder and depression, and highlighted the urgent need for access to quality mental health clinicians. Such overdue recognition has now backfired and mobilized opposition to parity, which would broaden access to service (front page, Nov. 6). People who battle severe psychiatric symptoms must also fight this pervasive discrimination and archaic stigma. The opposition to parity defies our surgeon general, who has advocated for more diagnosis and treatment, and the economics that has demonstrated that any modest cost is offset by increased productivity and decreased absenteeism.
docs.abstract: Sue Matorin letter on Nov 6 article scores lobbying against parity for mental health coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: Yohannes Gezu is one of the economic casualties of the terrorist attacks. A well-paid waiter at a big Chicago convention hotel before Sept. 11, he is now lucky to get a few days of work a week. Just as troubling for a man with a stay-at-home wife and a 1-year-old son, Mr. Gezu says he will also soon be confronted with paying a $400-a-month premium if he wants to keep his family's health insurance. ''How can you afford to pay $400?'' he asks.
docs.abstract: Economic downturn poses threat to health care needs of many Americans, especially low-income people; 65 percent of Americans under 65 receive insurance through employer, and if they lose their jobs, they must pick up full cost of premiums, which can be $500 to $600 a month; state officials and health care experts say basic government safety net for covering low-income workers is under increasing strain because of declining tax revenues, rising health care costs and expected jump in Medicaid caseload because of layoffs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Furious Lobbying Is Set Off by Bill on Mental Health'' (front page, Nov. 6): Older and disabled Americans who need mental health treatment suffer from the same coverage discrimination as employees. Medicare covers only half the cost of mental health care but 80 percent of other medical care. And Medicare imposes a 190-day lifetime limit for psychiatric hospital stays but none for general inpatient care.
docs.abstract: Medicare Rights Center president Diane Archer letter on Nov 6 article urges all insurers, including Medicare, to treat reimbursements for mental and other health care equally/

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The bill in Congress establishing mental health parity will not only benefit people with mental illness, but it will also fulfill the civil rights mandate of equality as established by the Americans With Disabilities Act (front page, Nov. 6). The cost of mental health treatment is overwhelming, particularly for people who are just entering the work force. Inadequate insurance coverage is a major barrier that discourages people with mental illness from seeking employment. For example, a person who is ready to return to work might be discouraged from doing so because the cost of mental health treatment may be more fully covered by Medicaid, which he would risk losing by earning income.
docs.abstract: Carl Herr letter on Nov 6 article backs bill to mandate parity for mental health coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a quiet confidence about Amy Callahan of Hoboken, N.J. She is 30 and petite, and she measures her words in a way that befits her profession as a special-education teacher in nearby Springfield. She occasionally stumbles, though, when speaking of Scott Hazelcorn. Mr. Hazelcorn was her fiancé, a 29-year-old bond broker at Cantor Fitzgerald who was killed in the World Trade Center attacks. She called him Haze. ''I'm having to call him Scott so much these days,'' she said. ''It's strange for me.''

headline.main: Dreams of a Summer Camp Take the Form of Reality

docs.abstract: Amy Callahan, whose fiance, Scott Hazelcorn, was killed in World Trade Center attacks, has created Scott Hazelcorn Children's Foundation with plans to open summer camp for children affected by that tragedy; says idea for summer camp grew out of conversation she and Hazelcorn had last summer, talking of their experiences as campers when they were children, and later as camp counselors; as news of foundation spreads, checks stream in, and relatives and friends are raising money at rallies and other events; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Oct. 4, Kirk Evans had his grandmother drive him to the Army recruiting station, a storefront wedged between a tanning salon and a window-blind shop in a strip mall a few miles from his home in Bloomington, Ill. It was one day after his 19th birthday and three days before the United States began bombing Afghanistan. Mr. Evans did not see himself as obvious soldier material.

headline.main: A Self-Described Slacker Decides He's Ready to Be a Soldier

docs.abstract: Article in series Enlisted Man profiles Kirk Evans, 19-year-old from Bloomington, Ill; self-described slacker, Evans enlists in army after watching news of Sept 11 terror attacks; photos (M)
